Make the 'dest' attribute optional, to facilitate use of the 'get' task for 
simple web site testing, e.g. for verifying that all jsps on a server compile.

Also, allow several urls to be specified, perhaps providing a 'base' attribute 
to shorten the specified urls...

creator: stevel@apache.org
text:
I should add that the reason it isnt in the main codebase is not that it doesnt
work, but that java.net.http is blazingly inconsistent across versions, and
w.r.t the http specs. If we went to httpclient we'd fix this, but if we shipped
as is now, we couldnt introduce a dependency on httpclient later on. And if we
depend on httpclient, we need to fix on a version (Axis is debating pulling
their support out till a 1.0 version of the httpclient ships, as it is too hard
to field calls against the many nightly builds that people use).

Nb, for jsp compilation and other web site testing, look at httpunit

I'm using <get> to update a wiki-page with the Versions of my just build 
program. This looks like

 <get src="http://server/wiki/patch_wiki.pl?
id=VersionList&before=1&marker=1&text=....." />

The Problem: text is "|| 2004/05/28 14:57 || [http://...... and so on for 3 long 
lines"

It's really annoying to do URLEncoding by hand!

Something like <get src="http://server/wiki/patch_wiki.pl"
 querysitring="somthing thats get URLEncoded" >
 and / or some <param name="gets URLEncoded" value="gets URLEncoded" />
 </get>
would be fine!
